div.head: THE EGYPTIAN GAZETTE
No. 7,437] ALEXANDRIA, WEDNESDAY, MARCH 7, 1906. [EIGHT PAGES P.T. 1.
The Eastern Telegraph Company, Limited.
div.p:
This Company's system of submarine telegraph
cables is the most direct and quickest means of
communication from Egypt to Europe, North and
South America, East, South and West Africa,
India, Australia, New Zealand, China and Japan.

To secure quick transmission, telegrams should
be marked Via Eastern.

For latest average time to London, see daily
bulletin in this paper.

Suez, Port-Tewfik, Port-Saïd, Suakin. Head

div.head: Peninsular and Oriental S. N. Company.
div.p: Berths can be definitely engaged beforehand. Plans can be seen at the Offices of the Company's Agents.

The through Steamers for Marseilles, Gibraltar, Plymouth and London are Intended to leave Port Said after the arrival of the 11 a.m. train from Cairo, every Monday. A steam tender will meet the train to convey passengers to the ship.
The Brindisi Express Steamer leaves Port Said directly the Indian Mails arrive. Passengers can go on board the evening before.
The express steamer usually reaches Brindisi on Wednesday afternoon, the special train starting at 8 p.m. and arriving in London at the very convenient hour of 4.56 p.m. on Friday.
The combined Sea and special train fare is £22.9.11 Port Said to London via Brindisi or via Marseilles.
Passengers having paid fall fare in one direction are allowed an abatement of 25 per cent, on returning within 12 months.
In addition to the above regular weekly service there are sailings about twice a fortnight of 5,000 to 7,000 tons steamers to London, calling at Malta or Marseilles.
TO THE EAST.

The Mail Steamers leave Suez for Aden and Bombay every Wednesday, and for Australia and China every alternate Wednesday. A steamer leaves for Calcutta, fortnightly, and another for Japan. Passengers can embark at Port Said.
For all further information apply to the Company's Agents,
Messrs. THOS. COOK & SON (Egypt) Ltd. CAIRO.
GEORGE ROYLE, Esq. PORT-SAID.
Messrs. HABELDEN & Co. ALEXANDRIA.
F. G. DAVIDSON, Superintendent P. & O. S. N. Company in Egypt SUEZ.

div.head: KHEDIVIAL MAIL LINE.
div.p: Express Steamers leave Alexandria every Wednesday at 4 p.m. for PIRAEUS, SMYRNA, MITYLENE, and CONSTANTINOPLE, in connection with Orient Express train-de-luxe for Vienna, Paris, and London.

Fast steamers leave Alexandria every Saturday at 6 p.m., and Port Said every Sunday at 6 p.m., for JAFFA (for Jerusalem), CAIFFA (for Nazareth), BEYROUT (for Damascus), TRIPOLI, ALEXANDRETTA, MESSINA, continuing in alternate weeks to LARNACA and LIMASSOL (Cyprus).

Steamers leave Suez fortnightly on Wednesday at 6 p.m. for JEDDAH, SUAKIN, MASSOWAH, HODBIDAH, and ADEN ; and in the intervening weeks for PORT SUDAN and SUAKIN direct. Calls will be made at TOR (for Mount Sinai) as required.
N.B.—Deck chairs provided for the use of passengers, excellent cuisine and table wine free.
Steamer plans may be seen and passages booked at the Company's Agencies at Alexandria, Cairo, Port Said, and Suez, or at THOS. COOK & SON or other Tourist Agency.

div.head: Austrian Lloyd's Steam Navigation
div.p: Alexandria-Brindisi-Venice-Trieste.

Weekly Express Mail Service. Steamers leave Alexandria every Saturday at 4 p.m. arrive at Brindisi, Tuesday a.m. in time for Express to Milan, Lucerne, Paris, Vienna, Berlin, and London, leaving Brindisi at 7 a.m. Arrival at Venice every Wednesday at about 8.80 a.m. in time for the Express to Switzerland, Paris, and London, leaving Venice at 2 p.m. and 11.20 p.m. Arrival at Trieste every Wednesday at about 3 p.m. in connection with the Train de Luxe Trieste-Vienna-Ostende. Passengers reaching London every Friday 4.50 p.m. Passengers from Cairo will find special through carriages and Luggage-Van attached every Saturday to the Express Train leaving Cairo at 9.30 a.m. and will be conveyed directly to the Quay alongside the steamer.
Fortnightly Service: Alexandria-Brindisi & Trieste Line

div.head: THE NATIONAL HOTEL, Cairo
div.p: One of the finest and most up-to-date Hotels in the Metropolis. Situated in Sharia Soliman Pasha, the very centre of the healthiest and most fashionable quarter. Stands in its own grounds with garden and lawn tennis grounds at back. Over 350 rooms and 5 saloons. Magnificent salle à manger. Handsome covered promenade verandah, 80 yards long. Highest class cuisine, electric light throughout, and lifts. English comforts. Rooms and apartments at prices to suit everyone. For further particulars apply to GENERAL MANAGER, Cairo.

div.head: EGYPT AND TURKEY.
div.p: The departure of the Turkish officers recently dispatched from Constantinople to discuss the Turco-Egyptian frontier question, after a stay of a week, from the beginning to the end of which neither of the delegates showed any official sign of life, adds another to the list of amusing incidents which enliven the study of recent Ottoman history. Ten days ago the departure from Constantinople of the two Offiicers of the Ottoman General Staff was taken by the home Press as an earnest of the readiness of the Forte to settle the frontier dispute that had unhappily arisen between Egypt and her de jure suzerain.The delegates duly arrived, and from the day of their arrival to the day of their departure they might have been concealed in the lowest depths of the hypothetical temple beneath the paws of the Sphinx for ail that was heard of them. Their departnre was as unostentations as their stay, and we suppose the Egyptian Foreign Office most still possess its soul in patience and await the next move on the part of the Porte. In the meantime, there is, we believe, no reason to fear any forward movement on the part of the Turkish troops encamped between Medaware aod Akaba and at Akaba itself, which might result in any further acts of trespass on territory that has long been Egyptian. The occupation of Tabah itself is in no sense a menace, and we imagine that the Turkish commander on the gulf, who has been promoted to the rank of Pacha for his bold act of initiative in occupying one of the few spots near Akaba which are habitable (though with difficulty) by any but Bedouins, has no desire whatever to exacerbate the dispute by any impetuous action. No one believes that serious consequences can result from the feet that the only palm tree visible for miles in a horrid waste is now sheltering some ragged Nizams, and those who see in every foreign complication that affects in the slightest degree the British Empire or any allied or friendly Government the hand—mailed and gauntleted—of a certain European Power, should read their "Anti-Jacobin" and reflect before they ask again, "Who fills the butchers' shops with large blue flies?" Similar incidents have occurred at Dthala, on the Aden frontier, and on the Persian Gulf, and Ottoman diplomacy has in the past done marvels to obtain a few acres of sand. But in the present case, while there is no cause for alarm, there is every reason for firmness on the part of the Egyptian Government, and we anticipate that its remonstrances will in the end commend the attention of the Forte, and that the Turco-Egyptian frontier will be scientifically detimitated.

div.head: THE EXCAVATIONS AT THEBES.
div.p: Professor Naville and Mr. C. T. Correlly contribute to the "Times'' an interesting account of the discovery of the Shrine of Hathor at Thebes.

For the last two years, they state, the explorers of the Egypt Exploration Fund—Prof. Naville, Mr. Hall, Mr. Ayrton, and Mr. Currelly — have been engaged in digging out the oldest temple that is known at Thebes. It belongs to the XIth dynasty to the King Menthuhetep Neb-hepet-Ra. This temple is built on a platform, to which access is given by a ramp, and is remarkable because it has middle a great block of maioury, the purpose of which is not known, but which may have been the base of a pyramid.

This year then efforts have been directed towards the bank part of the temple; the wished to see how it ended and how it was connected with the mountain at the end or the amphitheatre of Deir-el-Bahari. In the first part of the season Mr. Hall discovered the enclosure wall and found that the enclosure was interrupted by a court or wide avenue, lined on both sides by a single row of columns, and directed towards the mountain. The rock had been out open to make way for the avenue.
On the north side of the court, over the enclosure of the old temple, the found remains of a shrine of the XVIIIth dynasty, of the great King Thothmes III.

"This building made of big blocks of sandstone, did not cover a very large area, and is badly destroyed. A first encouragement was a fine statue of a scribe who lived at the end of the XIXth dynasty. As this statue was quite perfect, it seemed to us that it could not be alone. In this respect our hopes were deceived; we found no other statues; but suddenly the removal of a few stones revealed to us a chapel covered with sculptures, the colours of which are absolutely fresh. It is about 10ft. long and 5ft. wide. The roof is vaulted, painted in blue with yellow stars. This chapel is dedicated to Hathor, the goddess of the mountain of the West, who generally has the form of a cow. The goddess has not left her sanctuary. In the chapel is a beautiful cow of life size, in painted limestone, reddish brown with black spots. Ths head, horns, and flanks have evidently been overlaid with gold. The neck is adorned with papyrus stems and flowers, as if she were coming out of the water. She is suckling a little boy, who is again represented as a grown man, under her neck. The cartouche behind the head is that of Amenophis II., the son of Thothmes III., worse sculptures cover the walls."

This is the first time that a goddess has been found undisturbed in her sanctuary. Besides, no cow has ever been found of such size and superb workmanship. The modelling of the animal is exquisite, and the distinctive characters of the Egyptian cattle of the present day are reproduced. The statue is uninjured except for a small piece of the right ear. The cow wears the special insignia of the goddess, the lunar disc between the horns surrounded by two feathers. There is so much life in her head, that she appears as if about to step out of her sanctuary ; when one approaches the piece, the effect is very striking. This is evidently the scene represented on the numerous paintings on linen that have been found in the neighbourhood.

The Government were immediately notified, and the same evening some soldiers arrived, who are on guard night and day. The statue will be removed to Cairo as soon as possible and the shrine also will probably be taken down and rebuilt in the museum. The value of there things is so enormous, and the difficulties of guarding them so great, that it is felt to be too serious a risk should they be left in the present position, especially as to the chances of pillage is added the possibility of destruction by falling rocks. This is a striking example of the interest which if attached to the excavations at Deir el Bahari. This majestic amphitheatre of rocks with its two temples is now one of the chief attractions of Thebes; and except what Mariette did in one of them, the uncovering of the temples is entirely due to the Egypt Exploration Fund, especially the discovery and clearing of the second one. It is most desirable that the work should be finished. We thought that we should come to the end during this year, but the avenue in the direction of the mountain will demand another campaign, for which we urgently solicit the support of all friends of antiquity, and especially of all who are interested in the land of the Pharaohs.

div.head: Shepheard's Fete.
div.p: Shepheard's annual fits de nuit has been postponed to Friday, 16th inst.

div.head: Connaught House.
div.p: A concert will be given on Thursday at 8.30 p.m. at Connaught House, Y.W.C.A., on the 13th inst.

div.head: Norddeutscher Lloyd.
div.p: The departures of the S.S. Hohengollern from Alexandria on the 14th and 28th March will not take place.

div.head: Quarantine.
div.p: Quarantine restrictions as against plague are now applied in Egyptian ports to arrivals from Perth, Fremantle, and Gersi.

div.head: The Mahreussa.
div.p: The S.Y. Mahroussa, which has been edited with turbine engines, is expected to return to Alexandria in about seven weeks' time.

div.head: The Brindisi Mail.
div.p: The mail from Europe, via Brindisi and Port Said, will arrive at 8 o'clock this afternoon and will be distributed at the G. P. O. at 4.45 p.m.

div.head: Reunion Ramlists.
div.p: The Sociere Reunion Ramliete is giving a masked ball, with, cotillon, at the Villa Margherita, San Stefano, on Saturday, 17th inst. Trams will run all night.

div.head: Shrager Brothers.
div.p: We draw the attention of our readers to the legal notice in today's issue re Messrs. Shrager Brothers, whose Alexandrian business is now vested in Mr. Alfred Danon.

div.head: Government Hospital.
div.p: The Public Health Department has appointed Dr. William Andrew Betts as physician of the first class attached to the Alexandria Hospital with a salary of L.E. 50 a month.

div.head: International Institute of Agriculture.
div.p: Isset Pacha Under-Secretary of State at the Ministry of Foreign Affairs, signed at Rome on the 27th ult. the protocol of Egypt's adhesion to the International Institute of Agriculture.

div.head: The New "Cadre."
div.p: Yesterday a Commission met at the Finance Ministry, under the presidency of Lord Edward Cecil, for the purpose of studying the new "Cadre" of employes. The other members of the Commission are Mesrs. Webb, Dunlop, Brunyate, and Carter Wilson.

div.head: A Curious Mistake.
div.p: The detention of the North German Lloyd's S.S. Hohensollers has led to a strange error on the part of the London Press, who imagined it was the Kaiser's yacht. For example, the "Morning Poet" of last Wednesday remarks: "The German Imperial yacht Hohenzollern has arrived at Suda Bay. The Archduke Joseph of Austria is on board."

div.head: Bank Robbery.
div.p: Yesterday morning a Berberee servant of a business house at Alexandria want to the Credit Lyonnais to pay in a sum of money amounting to P.T. 118 750 which was in cash and banknotes. While waiting at the counter the banknotes value P.T. 110,000 (£1.200), disappeared. The Berberee suspected three Europeans who happened to be by him at the time but he could not identify them. No arrests have yet been made.

div.head: DELEGATION MUNICIPALE
div.p: (Communication Officielle)
La Delegation Municipale s'est reunie le 6 mars 1906 a 4 h. p.m. sous la presidence de M. Amb A. Ralli.
Presents M.M. Escoffier, Benachi, Baron A. de Menasce. O. Rothacker, Dr. Schiess Pacha, G. Zervudachi, membres. W. P. Chataway, administrateur, I. Sedky Bey, secretaire.

La Delegation decide de majorer de L.E. 17,450 le montant des assurances des divers biens meubles et immuebles appartenant a la Municipalite et charge l'administrateur d'operer la repartition de ces assurances entre les differentes societes.

Communication est dounes d'une lettre du 28 fevrier 1906 de S. E. le Ministre de l'Interieur informant qu'il approuve la nouvelle disposition votes par la Commission et portant modification aux reglements sur le fonds commun d'assurance contre la saisie des animaux de boucherie.

La Delegation prend egalement note d'une lettre du 3 Mars de S.E. le Ministre de l'Interieur donnant le texte definitif de la disposition a inserer dans le reglement vote par la Commission pour la malleinisation des solipedes des ecuries de la Societe protectrice des animaux.

La Delegation renvoie a l'examen du Comite des Travaux Publics une proposition de la Societe des Tramways tendant a proceder simultanement a la construction de la ligne Rond Point Hadra Canal et a celle de la ligne du nonveau quai.
Elle adjuge a M. Furat an prix de P.T. 19 le m.l. la fourniture de 6,000 m.l. de bordure, pierre de Naples; le restant de la fourniture, soit 9,000 m., sera mis de nouvean en adjudication.

Les recettes de la Municipalite du 1er Janvier a fin Fevrier 1906 sont de L.E. 32,465 pour le budget ordinaire et de L.E. 80,487 pour le budget extraordinaire; les depenses sont de L.E. 27,185 et L.E. 7,008 respectivement pour les deux budgets.
La séance est levee a 7 h. p.m.

div.head: ANGLO-SPANISH ALLIANCE. TO HERALD KING ALFONSO'S WEDDING.
div.p: The Algeciras correspondent of the Paris "Journal" today states in a positive manner that the conclusion of a complete Anglo-Spaniah Alliance will herald the wedding of King Alfonso to Princess Ena of Battenberg.

div.head: TSAR TO OPEN DUMA.
div.p: The St. Petersburg correspondents of the Paris "Matin" today states that the Tsar, during the course of a conversation with some members of his immediate, entourage, signified his willingness to preside at the opening of the Duma.

div.head: THE ARMY ESTIMATES.
div.p: No striking changes have been decided on yet in the Army Estimates, but the home defence Army Corps has been completely abandoned. The use of the short guns has been confirmed, and they will be served out in England first, before India.

div.head: "MODERN EGYPT." SIR A. COLVIN'S NEW WORK.
div.p: Sir Auckland Colvin's important new book on Egypt, entitled "Modern Egypt." was very favourably reviewed in yesterday's London papers.

div.head: THE SHEIKH EL-SADAT.
div.p: "Al Zaher" states that Sheikh el-Sadat married two wives on the same day last month. The Sheikh, on the 24th February, married the lady Amineh Hanem, surnamed Um-Mahmond, daughter of Youssef Effendi, and also the lady Gulabar Hanem, one of the "Sirriehs'' of the late Khedivial lamail Pacha. The Sheikh has now four wives. Meanwhile, he is bringing another action against our esteemed confrere, Sheikh Aly Youssef, editor and proprietor of "Al Moayad," demanding the dissolution of his daughter's marriage with him.

div.head: FRENCH HOSPITAL AT CAIRO.
div.p: The Committee of the French Hospital at Cairo met on Monday afternoon under the presidency of M. de la Bouliniere, hon. president, and M. Raffye. The accounts of the hospital, which were admitted, were evidence of its increasing sources and popularity among patients of all nationalities. In the name of the board M. de la Bouliniere congratulated Dr. Brossard on the well-deserved distinction recently granted him by the French Government, in graceful and appropriate terms. At the same meeting M.Paul Pastour was appointed advisory engineer to the hospital.

div.head: EGYPT'S EXPORTS TO MANCHESTER.
div.p: At the annual meeting of the Manchester Ship Canal Company held last week, the Chairman, Mr. J. K. Bythell, reviewing the previous year's trade, stated that the position with regard to Egyptian cotton was very satisfactory. A much larger proportion of the exports from Egypt had been shipped to Manchester. They had an increase of 35,000 bales, and as a bale of Egyptian was about half as heavy again as a bale of American the increase was equal to 50,000 bales of American. The total cotton imported into Manchester was 649,000 bales in 1905, as compared with 538,000 bales in the preceding year, the increase being 111,000 bales. Those figures showed no sign of restriction, because spinners knew the advantages of having cotton handled at Manchester docks, and knew that concessions offered by Liverpool were the direct outcome of their competition. Spinners were not likely to be tempted by the inducements of through rates from the ships to the mills held out by Liverpool. They knew that if the competition of Manchester was driven away the offers and concessions would be withdrawn, and they also knew that if they fell to the temptations offered they would be adopting a most suicidal policy.

div.head: THE PILGRIM ROUTE.
GOOD RIDDANCE.
SEVEN BEDOUIN CHIEFS BEHEADED.
div.p: News comes from Mecca that the Sherif has captured and beheaded seven Bedouin chiefs who had for years been the terror of the pilgrims. The news is excellent bat we doubt whether each fitful and sporadic displays of severity will have any permanent effect "An Amurath to Amurath succeeds," and it is more than probable that in a few years' time we shall hear that seven other chiefs worse than the first seven are infecting the pilgrim route.

div.head: EGPYT AND TURKEY.
div.p: THE FRONTIER DISPUTE.

There is no further news from Akaba, and nothing is known with any certainty of the destination of the Turkish envoys. It is surmised that after a rest at Beyrout, which will enable them to recover from the fatigues of their journey and the strain of the negotiation of the past week, they will proceed to Damascus and after quaffing the waters of Abana and Pharpar make their way by leisurely stages to Akaba by way of Deraa and Ma'au.

div.head: RETURN OF THE KHEDIVE.
div.p: H.H. the Khedive returned to Alexandria last night from his excursion to the Western Desert and proceeded to Montazah Palace. His Highness will probably leave today for Koubbeh Palace, and come in to Abdeen Palace tomorrow morning.

div.head: TOR QUARATINE CAMP.
div.p: The following telegram has been received from the director of the Tor quaratine camp :––
Tor 6 Mars 1906.
Docteur Gotachlich a isole du cadavre d'un autre pelerin anatoliote un vibrion donnant la sero-reaction du vibrion cho'erique dans dilution serum specifique de un a deux mille.

div.head: IMPORTANT SALES OF BUILDINGS IN CAIRO.
div.p: The largest of the three big buildings belonging to the Messrs Coronel, situated immediately opposite the National Bank of Egypt in Sharia El Madabegh, Cairo, has just been sold to two Syrian gentleman, named Selim and Jacques Sabet, for £70,000, at which price the property gives only a little over 8 per cent annual interest, the present rental of the whole house being £2,400 a-year. The building is one of four stories and the area covered is 1,890 square metres.

Another important sale just concluded, and to which we referred yesterday, is that of the property of Mme. Adly Pacha Yaghen, wife of the Governor of Cairo, which consists of a large residence and abont 6,600 square metres of land, situated at the Rond Point, Kasr-el-Nil. opposite the palace of Ghazi Mukhtar Pacha. This was purchased by Prince Djemil Toussoun on behalf of a financial group of which the Prince and the Hotel Ritz in Paris form a part, at £120,000, or a little over £18 per square metre.
The same syndicate hold an option of purchase of the property known formerly as the Pension Fink, consisting of some 7,000 square metres at the price of £92,000.

As a proof of the immense appreciation in the value of building sites in the Kasr-el-Nil and Ism-ilieh quarters of the Metropolis, we may mention that the house and ground in question was bought by Mme. Fink some seven years ago––when she sold her former house in Sharia Kars-el-Nil to the Bank of Egypt––from Abdel Kader Pacha, a former Minister of the Interior, for £14,000. It was acquired by pre-emption last year for £42,000 by Osman Bey Cherif, and now the latter asks £92,000 and will most probably obtain this price.

div.head: THEWFIKIEH NILE COMPANY.
div.p: The above ill-starred concern, which came to an untimely end in 1904 is, we understand, about to pass into the possession of an English group. Negotiations between the liquidators of the company in Cairo and the would-be purchases in London have been going on now for some time, and a final decision is expected in the course of the next few days. It would be a good thing for the numerous creditors of the Thewfikieh, as well as for the shareholders, if the negotiators succeed, as in the event of failure at the eleventh hour the former would probably receive a small percentage of their claims and as for the latter they could hope for a very little return of the capital they invested in the company ; since at the time of its suspension the liabilities amounted to about £40,000 and the assets were estimated at less than one-half that sum. Even then the heirs of the late Menshawi Pacha have, we believe, a prior claim on such assets as can be realized, and these would not amount to much as the fleet consists of a few old and worn-out river steamers, besides two or three useless barges.

div.head: STEAMER MOVEMENTS.
div.p: The Ellerman S.S. Bosnian sailed from Malta last night and is due here on Saturday morning with a general cargo.

div.head: THE YOM ASHURA.
CURIOUS RELIGIOUS RITE.
EXTRAORDINARY CAIRO PROCESSION.
div.p: There are comparatively few of the visitors to Cairo who realized that on Monday night was enacted one of the most curious and painful religions rites which has come down from barbaric ages. To enter into a historic and accurate account of the reasons for this yearly penance is superfluous, for as this day is the anniversary of the death of Hassan and Hussein the grand sons of Mohamed who fell at the battle of Kerbala, so is it the great day of penance and atoneu ent among the Persian population. A large earn of money is paid yearly by this community to ensure that the streets may be kept free for their procession of abasement, and which follows over the route taken by the murderers so many generations ago. It in one of the great events of the year and is watched by many thousands of the natives, and for hours before the celebration is due the streets are lined with eager crowds of spectators, while every window on the ronte is crowded with women of every Eastern race. As the procession takes place at night-time there is no lack of colouring in the preparations, though the procession itself contains many elements likely to excite the susceptibilities of European onlookers.

Long lines of wavering torches and flags, each with a speoial emblem, heralded, the approach of those who had undertaken to do honour to Hassan stripped to the waist, with shaven heads and gyves upon their wrists. A certain number of these proceeded up the streets beating their breasts and lashing themselves from time to time upon their backs and shoulders with the heavy chains, only ceasing at the interference of those around them. They were followed by horses carryiog suits of armour, and a third covered with hangings dyed with ghastly stains. More torches threw up into high relief the long double string of other penitents in white, who, with sharp swords in their hands, kept on a ceaseless moaning of Hassan Hussein, striking their shaven heads the while with their instruments of torture till all their garments ran with blood. From time to time their frenzy would get the better of them, and the population would interfere to prevent them from doing themselves to death, and several tiny boys were included among them, all eager to emulate.

As the route followed covered the streets between the mosque of Hussein to the Citadel, the spectacle at the finish must have been little short of horrifying. It is said to be necessary to place a guard of armed soldiers before the door of the afore mentioned mosque, as the frenzied participants in the procession would almost certainly kill themselves outright if they could force themselves within its precincts their elders.

Many former accessories of this gruesome procession have been now abolished and it is under the rigorous supervision of the police but even now it remains a most curious; impressive, and yet most terrible testimony to the religious fervour of the Eastern races. Many of its details are difficult to follow or to understand, and the guidebooks are curiously reticent upon the subject. It remains for an abler pen than this to do the subject justice.

div.head: NOTES FROM PORT SAID.
div.p: Port Said, Tuesday.

Much has already been said about the necessarily cruel way in which cattle are landed here. Aa a role they are slung from the steamers by the horns, or legs, and no care is taken as to whether they are lowered into the barges gently or not. The result is that many animals get bumped about, legs get broken, and in some cases the horns have been almost – if not quite – torn out. This is bad enough, but there is further suffering when the barges are being unloaded. The barges are lower than the landing stage and the cattle must scramble out or get hauled out. Only last Saturday when some cattle were being landed one poor beast got a fore-leg badly broken, so it was bound on a cart and jolted away in a most brutal manner. It may not be considered necessary to handle these animals gently, as most of them are brought here to be slaughtered, but the slaughtering should take place at the proper time, and if all cattle had to be landed under the supervision of some specially appointed person, many unpleasant sights, now witnessed, could be avoided.

It is rumoured that the well-known Paris house "Printemps" contemplate opening a branch here, and have already taken large premises. This will be very welcome news to the ladies who have been oomplaining for a long time that it is very difficult to obtain what they require locally. The shop-keepers here do not show sufficient enterprise, and if the rumour referred to is fulfilled, they will be sorry for not having kept pace with the needs of the fair sex.
Port Said is attracting the attention of the land companies, and lately representatives of the new concerns have been here looking round. The result of these visits may be known shortly.

div.head: WINDSOR HOTEL Restaurant.
div.p: Table d'Hote Luncheons & Dinners Served on the Terrace.

div.head: AN AMERICAN ON EGPYT.
DR. BEDLOE'S IMPRESSIONS.
OF A TOUR IN UPPER EGYPT.
div.p: Dr. Bedloe, of Washington, D.C., with his host and college class-mate Dr. Love, returned to Alexandria last night after an extended tour, by river and rail, of Upper Egypt. Although Dr. Bedloe has made several trips up the Nile, since his first visit to Egypt in 1880, this latest tour has opened his eyes to many "changes for the better," as he puts it, 'that have come to remain for the benefit of all in the land of the Nile.'

He speaks enthusiastically of the bright future for this attractive country in general and of the southern regions in particular where the great Nile barrage at Assouan is working wonders in enriching the land for miles and miles, and where once was sterile sand now the country smiles with fertility.

An interesting feature is Alfalfa, or "California Clover," so called by reason of the fact that the seed was brought to Egypt from the Golden Gate, on the Pacific Coast of America, and planted here and in the Sudan by Mr. Leigh Hunt, the American agriculturist, who claims that it is superior to prolific and nutritions, and he says his plantation in the Sudan yields a crop of Alfalf every month.

div.head: Irrigation Administration.
div.p: Of the Egyptian administration Dr. Bedloe says the great irrigation system, so ably managed, has increased multifold the acreage of productive properties on both sides of the Nile and so enriched and enhanced the value of the land it now rents for from ten pounds sterling up to even twelve pounds the acre per month in the Nile Delta. Of the river voyage, the equipment and service of the Nile steamers and dahabiehs, he says they are up to a high standard of excellence ; in truth, surprisingly satisfactory to all on board, and none speak of the service but to praise.

div.head: Railways.
div.p: As to the Egyptian railways, the wagon-lits and dining-car service, with its scrupulously clean and comfortable beds, and excellent table, electric lights and fans are all up-to-date between Cairo and Luxor. Beyond Luxor the narrow-gauge and similar limitations in other respects leave much to desired.

This weakness, it is understood, will soon be remedied by the introduction of the third rail, thus avoiding a change of cars at Luxor. The management also contemplate the adoption of the successful system of General George Boyd's Pennsylvania Railway personally conducted tours so popular in America, which General Boyd, the General in chief of the passenger department of the Pennsylvania lines, originated in 1887 and is now and has been for years a permanent and profitable feature of that great corporation.

div.head: Increased Facilities.
div.p: The railway facilities for seeing all of Egypt's wonders should be increased and improved to meet the demands of the constantly increasing number of tourists who come to Egypt from all the parts of the world. From the official report of the Egyptian Railway Administration it is shown that the receipts of the passenger department for January 1906, in excess of the figures given in the corresponding month of last year, show an increase of eighty thousand pounds sterling.

The increasing revenue justifies the contemplated improvements. The Administration, it is reported, has ordered several high-grade locomotives which will make the journey between Cairo and Alexandria in 2 hours, reducing the existing schedule time by one third.

div.head: Personally conducted.
div.p: The proposed system of personally conducted tours will create and attract travel in Egypt, and by dealing with the public direct will omit the middlemen and thereby give better rates and service to the traveller. The benefit to both the railway and the travelling public by the personally conducted tour system, cannot be over-estimated. It was General Boyd and his Chief of Staff, Colonel Frank Barksdale, who arranged the itinerary, equipped and directed the tours of Li Hung Chang, and also of Prince Henry of Prussia over the vast network of railways owned and controlled by the Pennsylvania Lines in America, and when this system shall be established on the railways of Egypt it will attract thousands, where only hundreds come now, of the vast number of people who desire the entertainment, instruction, and luxury to be obtained only on the banks of the Nile.
Dr. Bedloe and his party intend to leave for Europe by the North German Lloyd steamer next week.

div.head: PERSONAL AND SOCIAL.
div.p: Prince Leopold of Battenberg will arrive in Cairo from Upper Egypt on the 11th inst.
The Princess of Orleans have returned to Ghezireh Palace Hotel after a trip to Palestine.
Don Carlos, Duke of Madrid, and the Duchess of Madrid, accompanied by General de Medina and suite, are leaving Alexandria today for Europe by the North German Lloyd's S.S. Schleswig.
The Duchess of Madrid is a Rohan, and in view of the approaching marriage of the King of Spain, a correspondent of a London contemporary remarks :

The Rohans are one of the oldest and most illustrious houses in Europe, descended from the Crusader Kings of Jerusalem, and its members have time and again contracted alliances with the sovereign dynasties of Europe. Yet, one of the principal reasons which render the Pretender Don Carlos so strangely reluctant to reign at Madrid, and to enforce his alleged claims, is the knowledge that if he were to become King the Spanish aristocracy would decline to recognise as Queen his wife, the Duchess of Madrid, who was Princess Bertha of Bohan. Princess Ena, although she has a royal princess for a mother, is a niece of the King of England, and a first cousin of the Kaiser, nevertheless ranks in the eyes of the Continental aristocracy as a mere noblewoman, the daughter of a German nobleman whose honours were of modern creation. She does not even figure in Part II of the Almanach de Gotha, among they mediatised houses of Europe such as the Croys, the Pappenheims, the Qiadts, the Auerspergs, and the Beutincks, who are entitled to mate on a footing of equality with the reigning families, but belong to the ordinary aristopracy ; and, owing to this, her position as Queen of Spain will be a somewhat delicate due.

The Archduke Joseph and Archduchess Augusta of Austria arrived yesterday at Cairo by the midday train, and are staying with their suite at Shepheard's Hotel. Their Imperial Highnesses will shortly be leaving for Upper Egypt.
The Duke and Duchess of Argyll will stay at Cairo for a few weeks before proceeding to Europe.

Prince Faradjallah Khan, Persian Consul-General in the Caucasus who came to Egypt a few weeks ago for the benefit of his health, has resigned his position and intends to remain in Egypt until he has quite recovered his health. Mirza Mahmoud Khan, the Persian Consul-General at Calcutta, will replace Faradjallah Khan in the Cancasus.

Mr. John B. James, late Mayor of Plymouth, after having spent a few days in Nairobi, has proceeded to Lake Victoria Nyanza and Entebbe, from whence he intends making a journey to Cairo via Gondokoro and Khartoum.
The many friends of Mr. and Mrs. Mrs. McMillan in Egpyt will be interested in the following extract which we call from Mr. Longworth's "Globe Trotter." :––

From reports to hand it is evident that the opportunity of engaging in the fascinating and most exciting sport of all big game shooting is to be had in plenty by the enthusiast in the neighbourhood of Donya Sabok. Mr. and Mrs. Wm. N. McMillan, who have recently located on their large farm, are now on safari and from their bag for the first two days' shoot, the lions in their vicinity are likely to have a lively time. On the first day Mr. McMillan succeeded in getting a lion. On the second day the honours fell to Mrs. McMillan, who, with great deliberation and nerve, shot a magnificent specimen, hitting it twice in the head ; the brute charged but was stopped by Mr. McMillan and their guest Mr. Bulpitt. We congratulate Mrs. McMillan upon her early success and have no doubt that such a keen sportswoman will account for many trophies in the near future. If I am not mistaken this is the first lion kill to record by a lady in B. E. A.

div.p: BOXWELL.––On March 7th, at Ghesireh, Cairo, the wife of Philip R. Boxwell, of a son.

div.head:
ALGECIRAS CONFERENCE.
THE POLICE QUESTION.
OPTIMISM AGAIN PREVALENT.

div.p: The Russian delegate has submitted a proposal for a Franco-Spanish police force in Morocco as being the only solution. M. Revoil, supporting, said that France was prepared to organise 2,000 Moors at the eight principal ports. Baron Radowitz maintained that all the Powers should participate in policing in order to secure economic equality. The British, Spanish, and Portuguese delegates snpport M. Bevoil. (Reuter)
Official circles regard the situation with optimism. They consider that the suggestion of M. Revoil regarding police will meet with no opposition from Germany if guarantees are given. (Havas)

The Army Estimates amount to £29,796,000, showing a decrease of £17,000 despite the increase of £220,000 for the reserves, which it is expected will reach 122,000 men, and £290,000 for stores and clothing, owing to the exhaustion during the war. The surpluses will, practically speaking, simply provide for the carrying on of the army on its present footing. (Reuter)

The Budget Committee of the Reichstag has approved the addition of five large cruisers to the fleet, which will be employed abroad, ard the construction of two 18,000-ton battleships and one 15,000-ton cruiser. (Reuter)

The Army and Nary Board has recommended the putting in a state of defence the following places : Manila Bay, Pearl Harbour, Guantanamo, Guam Honolulu, and both entrances to the Panama Canal. The estimated cost would be 50,000,000 dollars.
President Roosevelt, in a Message to Congress, says that the insular possessions should not be neglected it if is desired to hold them. (Reuter)

div.head:
BULGARIA AND EGYPT.
COMMERCIAL CONVENTION SIGNED.

div.p: The Blugaro Egyptian commercial convention has been signed. It empowers Bulgaria to establish a diplomatic agency in Egypt. (R.)

div.head:
ROMAN CATHOLICS IN RUSSIA.
NEW LAW PROMULGATED.

div.p: A new law has been promulgated in Russia largely extending the privileges of Roman Catholics. (Reuter)
Mr. Kennard has been released. (Reuter)
King Edward has arrived. (Havas)
King Edward received a most enthusiastic send-off before leaving for Biarritz. (Reuter)
King Alfonso, the Princess Ena, and her mother have arrived here. (Reuter)

div.head: NEW ITALIAN AMBASSADOR TO ST. JAMES'S.

div.p: Count Tittoni has been appointed Italian Ambassador in London. (Reuter)
Baron Banffy has seceded from the Hungarian coalition. (Reuter)
According to an official despatch received here, though 327 houses have been destroyed at Papaiti, only one fatality is recorded. (R.)

div.head: Circulaire H. de Vries et Boutigny
NOTES ET CRITIQUES
div.p: Le Caire, 6 mars.
Le taux de l'escompte a Londres vient d'etre encore reduit de 1/8 a 3 1/2 pour cent, signe que les conditions du marche monetaire tendent de plus en plus a s'ameliorer.

Au Stock Exchange, hier, le Consolide anglais a cloture a 90 3/8, soit en reaction de 1/8 L'Unifiee est restee invariee a 105 1/4. La National Bank a hausse de 1/4 de livre a 27 5/8. L'Agricole a egalement gagne 1/4 a 10 1/4. Par contre, la Daira Sanieh a perdu 1/4 a 17 3/4.
A Paris, l'action Credit Foncier Egyptian a reactionne de 2 francs a 790. La Banque d'Athenes est demeuree inchangee a 146.
Notre marche des valeurs a presente ce matin beaucoup d'animation. La tendance a ete tres ferme, avec des cours en hausse sur la plupart des valeurs.

La National Bank, toujours delaissee, a cloture a son cours d'hier. Plus active, l'Agricole s'est incrite a 10 1/8-3/16 1'action ancienne et 9 3/4 la nouvelle. Eu bonne tendance, la Banque d'Athenes a hausse de 142 a 149. La Cassa di Sconto a progresse a 208 1'action ancienne et 206 la nouvelle.

L'action Credit Foncier est revenue a 790. La Daira Sanieh a progresse a 18 ; la Behera a 38 3/4 ; l'Immobiliere a 387 ; l'Agricole du Nil a 282 ; l'Enterprise and Development a 2 7/16, la part de fondateur a 15 3/4.
L'action Societe d'Entreprises Immobilieres et de Travaux a avance a 4 1/16 1/8 ; la part de fondateur a atteint L.E. 8 3/4.
Poursuivant son mouvement ascensionnel, 1'action ordinaire Khedivial Mail est allee jusqu'a 48 sh. pour cloturer a 45.3.

Dans le groupe des Hotels, les honueurs de la seance ont ete pour les Nungovich, pousses de 14 5/8 a 15 7/8-15/16, faute de titres en circulation et de vendeurs. Les Baebler ont avance a 5 13/16 et les Upper Egypt a 5 11/16.

Parmi les petites valeurs, les Delta Land ont cloture a 3 1/4 et les Hooker a 1 1/16. Les Estates ont ete cotes a 1 31/32 ; la part de fondateur a 9 3/16. Las Salt and Soda sont revenus a 25sh. 6 et les Cotton Mills a 6/3. Les New Egyptian ont avance a 31sh., les Glymenopoulo a 1 15/32 et les Egpytian Constructions a 1 9/16-5/8.

Les actions de la Societe d'Entreprises Immobilieres et de Travaux sont cotees officiellement depuis ce matin a la Bourse Khediviale en vertu d'une resolution prise hier soir, a l'unanimite des voix, par l'assemblee extraordinaire tenue par la Corporation des agents de change du Caire.

Le mouvement qui s'est dessine hier sur ce titre s'est accentue aujourd'hui. Cette bonne tendance est l'effet rationnel des resultats acquis par la nouvelle Societe. E. effet, elle est non seulement sur le point de conclure quelques affaires importantes appelees a lui valoir un benefice considerable, mais elle a deja realise de gros courtages sur plusieurs transactions de terrains traitees par son entremise.
Or, le profit donne par cette branche supplementaire de revenu suffit seul a assurer, d'ores et deja, le dividende de l'exercice en cours.

Nous apprenons que la Banque d'Athenes a accepte la proposition du gouvernement francais tendant a la nomination de deux administrateurs francais dans le conseil de cette Banqee Par consequent, les actions de la Banque d'Athenes seront admises au parquet de la Bourse de Paris. Voila, certes, une nouvelle appelee a accentuer la hausse sur ce titre.
On annonce d'Alexandrie que l'Egyptian Estates Co. vient de revendre une partie de la propriete qu'elle avait achatee dernierement a M. G. B. Alderson.
La cession aurait ete faite a un prix qui laisserait un benefice d'environ 120 pour cent a la Societe.
Les cours du coton sont arrives en baisse d'Amerique. Hier, le disponible a perdu 10 points, le Mai 11 et 1'Octobre 8.
Les arrivages ont ete de 13,000 balles contre 29,000.
Le marche de Liverpool est egalement en reaction sensible.
Ici, le Mars, qui avait fiui hier soir a 19 3/32, a ouvert ce matin a 19 5/16 pour cloturer a 19 11/32.

MM. H. de Vries et Boutiguy agents de change, se chargent de l'execution de tons ordres de Bourse (valeurs et marchandises) sur les marches de Londres, Paris, Bruxelles, Anvers, Liverpool et New-York. La Circulaire quotidienne de la maison est envoyee sur demande.

div.head: Important Announcement.
div.p: Steam Ploughing, Cultivating, Levelling and Grading.

Messrs. J. & H. McLAREN, Manufacturers of Steam Ploughing Machinery, Midland Engine Works, Leeds, now beg to announce to their friends in Egypt, that Mr. Henry McLaren, one of their principals, will be in Egypt for the month of March, 1906. He will be glad to make appointments with any interested parties to show them our steam plough tackle at work in Egypt, and will visit and inspect any lands on which it may be intended to work steam ploughs, and give must favourable prices for suitable Machinery.

He will also show them our new Patient Gaaobeah, or levelling scoop, at work, which is the most improved method of handling large quantities of sand or soil for levelling purposes which has yet been put upon the market.
Landed Propritors, agriculturists, and Contractors, are requested to communicate with Mr. McLAREN at Shepheard's Hotel, Cairo, after March 1st, 1906.

div.head: CAIRO POLO TOURNAMENT.
div.p: The Polo Tournament was continued on Saturday afternoon before a very large croud of spectators. It was a perfect day for polo, warm with no wind. The first game between the 60th and the Tourists was a real good game, one of the best so far during the tournament. It was anybody's game up to the last moment. The second game was not so good, being rather sticky and decidedly wanting in combination. The Tourists were without the services of Mr. De Freville, who is laid up with fever, but a very able substitute was found in Mr. Akers Douglas. The Tourists have now won all three matches so must play in the final.
1ST CHUKKER.

From the throw-in Seymour hit across the ground. Pickering got hold and hit well down the ground, Dalby returning to Eustace, who took the ball to the Tourists' goal, where Sparkes cleared. The Tourists then attacked and scored a subsidiary. From the hit-out Pickering returned with a good shot, just missing a subsidiary. Dalby hit out and Seymour took the ball down the ground to the Tourists' goal, where Dalby, with a fine long, shot, almost scored, Sparkes clearing in fine style. Eustace centred with a good shot and the 60th missed a good chance of scoring. Shortly afterwards Dalby met the ball and getting away made a good run, finishing up with a very nice stroke through the goal posts. 60th, 1 goal ; Tourists, 1 sub. A very good chukker with plenty of galloping.
2ND CHUKKER.

Give-and-take play followed the throw-in till Dalby took the ball down but hit behind. Eustace had a good chanoe of scoring from the hit-out but failed to make use of it. Sparkes hit out badly and the 60th hit behind. Rather sticky play followed the hit-out till Seymour got away and Pardoe sticking to his back well the 60th looked like scoring, but Pickering returned. Again the 60th attacked and running the ball down Seymour scored a very good goal with a beautiful near side shot at a difficult angle. From the throw-in Pickering hit up but Dalby returned and Akers-Douglas brought the ball back, and from a good centre by Sparkes Pickering hit a subsidiary. Result: 2 goals ; Tourists, 2 subs. The play was favour of the 60th, the Tourists being on the defensive most of the time.
3RD CHUKKER.

Dalby hit out in front of goal, giving the Tourists a chance which they falled to take advantage of. Seymour hit well up and Douglas returned. The Tourists now attacked Akers- Douglas, backing Pickering up well they took the ball down the ground, but Dalby cleared with a fine shot bringing the ball right round, and down the 60th went to the Tourists' goal when Sparkes returned. Shortly afterwards Eustace met the ball well and carried the ball down the middle of the ground, Dalby hitting a subsidiary. From the hit-out Pickering and Douglas ran the ball down, Eustace saving well. Again the Tourists attacked, Akers-Douglas centering with a good shot, but Paravicini missed a somewhat hard shot at goal. A good piece of play by Akers-Donglas followed, turning on the ball at mid-field first with a near shot and then a good off-drive he hit the ball up to Paravicini who hit a goal. Pickering got on from the throw-in when Dalby, misjudging the distance, dashed in to meet the ball, but it was too late and Akers-Douglas following up hit a goal. From the throw-in Dalby made a good run, but missed his final shot. Pickering hit well up from the hit-out Dalby returning with a good shot. The game was then stopped as Akers-Douglas's pony came down, giving him what might have been a nasty fall. Result: Tourists, 2 goals, 2 subs. ; 60th, 2 goals, 1 sub. A good galloping chukker in which the Tourists had rather the best of it.
4TH CHUKKER.

From the throw-in Eustace got away, but the Tourists returned the ball and rushing it up Sparkes missed a good chance of a goal. Again the Tourists attacked and Paravicini hit a subsidiary. The 60th could not get the ball away and Paravicini missed a real easy chance. Dalby hit out in front of goal and Paravicini meeting the ball nearly scored. Seymour cleared. The whistle blew just as Dalby got away, leaving the Tourists winners of a very good game. Result: Tourists, 2 goals 3 subs; 60th, 2 goals 1 sub.

The Tourists had very much the better of this chukker, the ball seldom being out of the 60th end. This was a good galloping game, in which there was plenty of good polo. There was little to choose between the teams. For the winners Sparkes again played well, he was very safe and on several occasions scored well. Considering Akers Douglas was playing ponies he had never seen before he played extremely well, especially in the last two chukkers. Pickering was not hitting so well as usual and Paravicini though hitting well does not stick enough to his back. Dalby should not have been allowed to gallop loose.

For the losers Dalby played brilliantly, being very safe, and in addition made several good runs. Pardoe played very well and stuck to his back all through, and especially in the first two chukkers bothered Sparkes considerably. Both Seymour and Eustace played much better than last match, the bitting of the former especially being both hard and clean.
The hitting out on both sides was bad, the 60th back repeatedly hitting out in front or across his own goal;–– a risky performance.
1ST CHUKKER.

From the throw-in Stockwell hit up and Brakenridge returned. For the majority of the chukker the ball remained in midfield till Bartlett got away and with a good shot centred well and Stockwell hit a goal. From the throw-in the Mosquitoes again attacked, Graham running the ball down and Stockwell hit another goal. Mosquitoes, 2 goals ; E.A., nil. Not a very good chukker, the game being sticky and a lot of missing.
2ND CHUKKER.

From the throw-in Rome got hold and took the ball down the side line, he centred with a fine shot very nearly scoring, Dudgeon saving well. The E.A. again attacked and missed a good chance of scoring, the ball going behind. From midfield Gordon took the ball down and Rome following up centred well, but Bartlett cleared in good style. The E.A. again attacked and looked like scoring but again Bartlett saved. Play was now confined to midfield till Bartlett taking the ball well with a near side shot got away and looked like getting a goal, but the ball bumped and Gordon returned. The E.A. now attacked and rushed the ball down where Bartlett missing a backhander allowed Broadbent to score a goal. Mosquitoes, 2 goals ; E. A. 1. A better chukker with more galloping.
3RD CHUKKER.

From the throw-in the E.A. attacked, Bartlett returning. Scrambling play followed till Bartlett made a run down, Rome returning with a fine backhander. The Mosquitoes then made a combined rush and Bartlett missed a good chance. From the hit-out Gordon got away and had a clear run but the ball bumped and Dudgeon returned. Bartlett and Graham then centred well and Dodgeon hit a goal. Give-and-take play followed, the E.A. very nearly scoring, the ball finally going out. Mosquitoes, 3 goals ; E.A., 1.
4TH CHUKKER.

From the throw-in Brakenridge might have scored but hit wide, the ball going behind. From the hit-out Stockwell made a good run taking the ball into E.A. territory, Brakenridge returning with a fine backhander. Up-and-down play followed in which Rome, Brakenridge, and Bartlett were conspicuous. The E.A. attacked but Bartlett saved with a good near side shot. Nothing farther happened, the whistle going with the ball in Mosquitoes' territory. Mosquitoes, 3 ; E.A. 1.

This was not a very good game to watch. There was good, individual hitting but a decided want of combination and too much missing. Repeatedly the E.A. forwards had the ball sent up to them, but they were unable to take the ball on. For the winners Bartlett played well. For the losers Rome and Brakenridge both hit well, the latter's backhanders being especially good.

div.head: BRITISH RIFLE CLUB (ALEX.)

div.head: DON'T NEGLECT A COLD.
div.p: Neglected Colds Lead to Consumption.
MISS LILLIAN POWELL Aurora IND.
PE-RU-NA CURES COLDS AND COUGHS.
How Pretty Miss Powell Was Restored to Health by Pe-ru-na.
Miss Lillian Powell, Aurora, Ind., writes:

"Last spring I caught a severe cold from getting my feet wet and being out in the rain, and in a day I had a most miserable cold, but I neglected it, thinking it would soon leave me. But it hung to me for two weeks, when I felt something must be done, as my condition was serious.

"I had heard so much about Peruna and in its praise that I bought a bottle and began taking it regularly. I was gratified to find that in a week the cold and cough was broken up, and three weeks' treatment completely restored my usual good health." --Lillian Powell.
How Consumption Develops.
Nine cases of consumption out of ten occur in this way:
A person catches cold. The cold is not properly cured, and another is caught.
This cold is dilly-dallied with, either by no treatment whatever or some treatment that is ineffectual, and the cold continues.
Then another cold is caught and a cough develops. Cough syrups are resorted to, but they give only temporary relief.
By and by the patient gets tired of taking medicines and cough syrups and gives up in despair.
The cold continues to develop and the cough grows worse.
The the doctor is called in, only to discover that the patient is in the first stages of consumption.
It was just in this way that Miss Powell, of Aurora, Ind., became sick. She caught a cold, and not considering it serious, neglected it, thinking as many others do, that it would "wear off."
However, it clung to her tennciously, and in two weeks she found her health in a serious condition.
Fortunately, Pertina had been brought to her notice, and she took a course of this remedy before it was too late.
In a week the cough and cold were broken, and a three weeks' treatment completely restored her to health.
This is what Peruna is doing all the while. Not a day, and probably not an hour passes in which someone does not have a similar experience with Peruna.
Cure the Slight Colds and Avoid Consumption.

The first step toward consumption is a cold. The next step is a failure to cure it promptly. The third step is the development of catarrh, which gradually becomes chronic. The fourth step, the catarrh begins to spread from the head to the throat, then to the bronchial tubes, and finally into the lungs. It is then consumption in the first stage.

At any time during the progress of catarrh, from the first-onset of the cold to its final settlement in the lungs, Peruna can be relied upon to stop the disease. If you have taken a cold, buy Peruna without delay. One bottle in the beginning will do more good than a half dozen bottles after the catarrh has fastened itself on the lungs.
Thousands of Testimonials.

We have on file thousands of testimonials from people who have been cared of catarrh of the lungs by Peuna. We can give our readers only a slight glimpse of the vast array of unsolicited endorsements we are receiving every month. No other physician in the world has received such a volume of enthusiastic letters of thanks as Dr. Hartman for Peruna.

For special directions everyone should read "THE ILLS OF LIFE" a copy of which surrounds each bottle. Peruna is for sale by all chemists and druggists at five shillings per bottle or six bottles for twenty-five shillings.

div.head: COUR D'APPEL MIXTE
div.p: L'Affaire des Sucreries.

Ce matin il y avait grande affluence de monde dans a salle d'audience de la Cour d'Appel Mixte pour entendre les plaidoiries de l'appel interjete par la Societe contre le jugement de premiere instance du Caire, qui a pronouce samedi dernier l'etat de faillite. Parmi l'assistance on remarquait M. Naus et l'Hon. Davey, administrators des Sucreries, le syndic de la faillite, M. Sampaolo, et de nombreux representants de la presse tant du Caire que de notre ville.
A l'appel de la cau ton de Wiart, avocat des Sucreries, a la Cour de plaider le plus vite possible, un surgence.
Le president a fixe a la plaidoiries de l'affaire, qui prendront un temps relativement long, une andience speciale qui aura lieu lundi prochain a 3 h. 1/2 p.m.
Societe Anonyme "Lowenbrau" at Consorts contre Societe Anonyme "Crown Brewery d'Alexandria."

On se rappelle que la Lowenbraii niait a la Crown Brewery le droit d'inscrire sur ses etiquettes "biere genre Munich," parce qu'il etait tout aussi impossible a la Brasserie Alexandrine de fabriquer de la biere genre Munich qn'au sol americain de produire du coton egyptien.
Cette these n'a pas ete admise par la Cour, qui, se basant sur les motifs invoques par les premiers juges, a deboute les appelants de leur appel comme mal fonde et les a condamnes aux depens.

div.head: TRIBUNAL MIXTE DU CAIRE.
div.p: Le proces des Freres.
Voici le texte du jugement rendu hier par la 2me chambre civile du Tribunal mixte du Caire dans l'affaire en dommages-interets Mazaltob et Mausour :
"Oui les parties en leurs-conclusions ; Vu les conclusions par ecrit et les pieces a l'appui;
Attendu qne les demandeurs se sont desistes de leur action, qu'il echet donc de leur en donner acte ;

Attendu quant a la demande reconventionnelle que le Tribunal tient a eclairer lui-meme sa religion vu les faits de la cause par une descente sur les lieux des evenements incrimines et par la comparution personnelle des parties.

Par ces motifs, donne acte aux requerants de leur action et, avant dire droit sur la de mande reconventionnelle, ordonne la visite des lieux et la comparution personnelle des parties. Dit que le Tribunal se transportera a cet effet sur les lieux des evenements incrimines au jour de jeudi le 8 mars 1906 a 4 heures de relevee et invite les demandeurs en reconvention d'y amener leurs fils Victor Mazaltob et Felix Mansour a telles fins que de droit. Depens reserves.

div.head: SOCIETS DES EAUX DU CAIRE
div.p: L'assemblee generale ordinaire de la Societe des Eaux du Caire s'est tenue vendredi passe au siege social au Caire.
Il ressort du rapport du Conseil d'administration que les benefices de l'exercice 1905 s'elevent a L.E. 107,251, contre L.E. 101,951 en 1904.
Le conseil a propose de distribuer 5 francs par action de capital; 8,25 par action de jouissance ; 50,60 par part de fondateur et 5.06 par dixieme de part de fondateur.
La proposition a ete acceptee, et ces sommes seront payees a l'echeance du 1er avril prochain.
Le dividende de francs 8,25 par action nouvelle represents une augmentation de 1 franc par action ancienne, sur celui de l'exercice ecoule.

L'augmentation dont on beneficie pour l'exercice 1905 est, en realite, beaucoup plus importante puisque, comme actionnaire, on a recu, pour chaque deux actions de la Societe des Eaux, une action de la Compagnie Frigorifique, et que cette derniere distribue pour cet exercice un dividende de 5 francs par action. C'est donc pour les actionnaires de la Societe des Eaux une augmentation de dividende de fr. 1 plus 2 fr. 50 soit 3 fr. 50.
M. J. B. Piot bey a ete elu administrateur de la Societe, en remplacement de feu Sir Elwin Palmer.

div.head: SOCIETE D'ENTREPRISES IMMOBILIERES ET DE TRAVAUX
div.p: Dans son assemblee extraordinaire, la corporation des agents de change du Caire a admis a l'unanimite a la cote officielle les actions de la Societe d'Entreprises Immobilieres et de Travaux.

Ces actions ont donne lieu, hier et avant-hier a d'importantes transactions et ont atteint le cours de Lst. 4 1/16-1/8 pendant que les parts de fondateur etaient demandees a L.E. 8 1/2 sans qu'il se presente de vendeurs.

Suivant toutes les apparences, il faut s'attendre a un tres proche monvement de hausse sur les actions, car une plus va'lue est pleinement legitimee par les resultats obtenus. En effet, la nouvelle Societe a deja realise de gros courtages sur d'importantes affaires traitees par son entremise et le dividends de l'exercics en cours est d'ores et deja plus que pleinement assure.
Au demeurant, la Societe est sur le point de conclure deux ou trois affaires importantes qu'elle avait a l'etude et qui sont appelees a lui donner un profit considerable.

div.head: EGYPTIAN CONSTRUCTIONS LTD.
div.p: Les lettres de repartition des Egpytian Constructions ont ete livrees a la poste vendredi dernier, ainsi que les cheques de la Societe. Ceux qui ne les auraient pas encore recus sont pries de passer a ses bureaux pour les prendre. Les actions seront pretes jeudi 15 courant.

div.head: BULLETIN DE LA BOURSE
div.p: (Aujourd'hui a midi et demie)

Les Estates et les Nungovich ont eu les honneurs da la matinee. En Estates, le cours de l'action est monte a 2 et celui de la part de fondateur a 9 7/8. Les Nungovich ont atteint un moment 16 7/8 pour finir a 16 ¼, soit en nouvelle hausse de pres d'une demi-livre.

En hausse egalement et tres echangee la Banque d'Athenes a 146 ; la New Egyptian s'avance a 32/9, la Crown Brewery a 217, les Building Lands a 4 ½, l'Union Fonciere a 6 9/16, l'Urbaine a 5 9/32, les Upper Egypt Hotels a 5 13/16, et le Banco di Roma a 127-128.
Les Egyptian Hotels reprennent de 5 ¼ a 6 1/8, les Sucreries a 19.
De 45/6 la Khedivial Mail Ordinary s'avance a 48 pour cloturer a 46.
En revanche, l'Investment reactionne a 1 11/32, la Salt & Soda a 25, le Comptoir a 5 5/8 et la part de jouissance Eaux du Caire a 280.
Les grosses valeurs, telles que la National, l'Agricole, la Daira, la Delta Light sont delaissees sux prix anterieurs. Leur tour viendra beintot.
La tendance generale est bonne.

div.head: RE MESSRS. SHRAGER BROTHERS.
div.p: WHEREAS by an Indenture dated the 15th day of February 1906 and made between Albert Birmingham Miller, the Official Assignee of Bengal, of the first part, Charles James March, Chartered Accountant, appointed in the Bankruptcy proceedings of the said Firm of Messrs. Shrager Brothers in England (thereinafter called the Trustee) of the second part, and Alfred Danon then and now residing in Alexandria Egypt, (thereinafter called the Purchaser) of the third part, the said Purchaser agreed with the said Official Assignee, for the consideration therein stated, for the absolute purchase from him of all his Estate and interest as such Official Assignee of and in the business and goodwill and the assets and outstandings of the said firm of Shrager Brothers as carried on in Alexandria ; And Whereas the said-Charles James March as Trustee agreed to join in the said Indenture for the purpose of confirming the said sale to the Purchaser, in respect of and to the extent of any interest that he might have in the said business assets and outstandings as such Trustee NOW NOTICE IS HEREBY GIVEN that in virtue of the said Agreement all the business goodwill and the assets and outstandings of the said firm of Shrager Brothers, as well as in respect thereto all the legal powers of the said Official Assignee and of the said Trustee have become vested in Shrager Brothers, as well as in respect thereto all the legal powers of the said Official Assignee and of the said Trustee have become vested in the said Alfred Danon.

Notice is HEREBY FURTHER GIVEN that the Power of Attorney date the 4th day of November 1905 and granted by the said Official Assignee to Carol Willem Dreckmeier of Alexandria has been cancelled as from the 26th day of January last and that the said Carol Willem Dreckmeier has no longer any authority thereunder to act in any way in relation to the affairs of the said firm of Shrager Brothers.

The said Alfred Danon has entered into occupation of the offices of the said firm of Messrs. Shrager Brothers, situate at No. 2 Rue Pirona, Alexandria, as his principal place of business in Egypt, where he will carry on the business of an Import and general merchant.
All persons indebted to the firm of Shrager Brothers are requested kindly to settle their accounts with the said Alfred Danon, whose signature alone will be valid.
Dated at Alexandria the 6th day of March 1906.
BRISCOE AND AICARD,
Advocates of the said Alfred Danon.

div.head: Daira Khassa de S.A. Le Khedive
div.p: AVIS
La Daira Khassa de S.A. le'Khedive a l'honneur d'informer le Public qu'elle met en vente aux encheres, une mouche a benzine nommee Edfinah ayant les caracteristiques suivantes:
Longueur 5 metres et 85 centimetres.
Largeur 1 metre cinquante centimetres.
Proue quarante cinq centimetres.
Poupe soixante dix centimetres.
Consommation : Un Kilog et demi de berzine a l'heure.
Vitesse a l'heure 10 Kilometres.
Les personnel qui desirent concourir a l'achat de la dite mouche pourront la visiter a I'Arsenal des Bateaux Khediviaux (Boulac).
Les offres devront etre presentees sous plis cachetes adressees a Son EXCELLENCE LE DIRECTEUR GENERAL DE LA DAIRA de S.A. LE KHEDIVE et accompagnees d'un cautionnemant de 10% ad valorem.
La Daira procedera le 20 Mars a 10 heures du matin a l'ouverture des offres L'adjudicataire taire devra payer au comptant le solde du ainsi que tons autres frais eventuels.

La Daira se reserve le droit d'acceptor ou de refuser l'offre la plus elevee et meme de ne donner aucune suite a l'adjudication sans que les soumissionnaires puissent avoir aucun recours contre Elle.––

div.head: MUNICIPALITE D'ALEXANDRIA
AVIS
div.p: La Municipalite met en adjudication la fourniture de gargouilles pour trottoirs avec accessoires.
Le cautionnement est fixe a LE. 40.
Le cahier des charges est depose au Bureau de la Voirie ou il peut etre consulte par les interesses tous les jours de 9 h. a midi, les jours feries exceptes.
Les offres devront etre adressees sous pli cachete a Monsieur l'Administrateur de la Municipalite avant le 3 Avril prochain.
Elles pourront egalement etre deposees en seance de la Delegation le meme jour a 5h. p.m.
L'enveloppe devra porter en outre la mention: "Soumission pour fourniture de gargouilles pour trottoirs."

Le cautionnement ou le recu d'une barque, d'apres les conditions du cohier des charges devra etre remis separement au Service de la Comptabilitie Generale avant l'ouverture des offres et au plus tard le 3 Avril prochain a midi.
Toute offre qui ne remplit pas les conditions ci-dessus sera ecartee.

Drach. 6 (six drachmes) par action, payable a partir du 3 Mars 1906:

div.head: Societe Anonyme des Eaux du Caire.
div.p: AVIS
Il est porte a la connaissance du public que le Conseil d'Administration de la Societe a decide de reduire de 22% le prix de l'ean fournie anx Bornes fontaines publiques.
Eu consequence, a partir du ler Janvier 1906 on pourra obtenir l'eau aux dites tontai nes a raison de P.T. 3 (trois piastres tarif) le metre cube au lien de P.T. 3,857 payees jusqu'ici.

Cette reduction de prix ayant ete decidee par la Societe dans le soul but d'en faire profiter les habitants de la Ville, le public est prie de veiller a ce que la dite reduction lui soit faite par les sakas qui lui fournissent l'eau, afin de ne pas laisser ces derniers profiter du rabais qui n'a ete consenti qu'en faveur du public.
La vente d'eau au detail aux Bornes fontaines, s'etablit donc comme suit :
Le tonneau de 660 kilos de jauge 20 millieme
Le guerbe de 66 kilos de jauge 2 millieme
L'estagnon de 22 kilos de jauge 3/4 millieme
et pour toute quantite depassant la jauge cidessus chaque 4 kilos seront comptes a 1/8 de milliemes.
Le Caire, le 19 Decembre 1905. Le Directeur
26974-30A-27 ASTLEY P. FRIEND.

div.head: Vade Mecum for the Homeward Bound
Picture Post Cards
div.p: "The Egyptian Gazette" Series is the most artistic collection to be found in Egypt.

div.head: TO OUR VISITORS
div.p: The Egyptian Gazette has much pleasure in presenting to its subscribers the accompanying description of some of the many interesting routes by which they may travel homewards. Great care has been taken to arrange them as accurately and concisely as possible, and it will be found that none of them are fraught with difficulty. In choosing the route home there are several things to be considered. To begin with there is the difference in climate between Egypt and the various points at which you may arrive in Europe.

This depends partly upon the month in which you leave Egypt, for Cairo in January may be a little warmer than the Riviera, and possibly not so warm as Sicily, but in March it will be warmer than Rome, and more uniformly warm than many other places in Europe. Many people leave Egypt far too early in the year, for as a rule the weather in April and May is perfect. The warmest place to go to on leaving Egypt is Sicily.

Some will want to take into consideration the number of days to be spent at sea, and we therefore subjoin a list showing the time occupied on each of the various routes between Egypt and the Continent of Europe.
They are as follows:-
The long sea routes—from Port Said or Alexandria to Plymouth, Southhampton, London or Liverpool—occupy about 4 days. The short ones are as follows:—

The steamers, of the P.&O. North German Lloyd, Orient and Messageriea Maritimes are the largest. The Anchor, British India, and Bibby Lines are also excellent, and their steamers are largely patronised by travellers to Egypt.
As regards the train journeys from Cairo, the shortest is that to Alexandria, without change (3 hours). That to Port Said, can now be made without change in 4 1/2 hours.

The least expensive way to England is by the Moss, Papayanni, Prince, and Westcott lines of steamers from Alexandria to Liverpool. The German Levant line has also good steamers from Alexandria to Hamburg.
The most expensive but quickest through Continental routes are by P.&O. Brindisi express from Port Said, and the Austrian Lloyd Trieste Vienna express from Alexandria.

As regards heavy luggage, it must be borne in mind that very little luggage is allowed free on the railways of Europe, but there are several good and responsible forwarding agents in Egypt who undertake at a fixed charge to deliver packages to any address in Europe.

The quickest manner of getting to Europe from Port Said is undoubtedly by the fast Mail Steamers "Osiris" and "Isis" to Brindisi. One of these leaves port Said every week, as soon as possible after receiving the Indian mails from the great liner arrived from Bombay.

These express steamer's have enormously powerful engines, and attain a very high rate of speed. They are called the "Ferry Boats" having been specially built to carry the British mail from Port Said to Brindisi. If you are going straight through to England you will find the train waiting at Brindisi which will take you to Calais without changing. It has complete arrangements for sleeping and eating on board, and you should arrive in London on the fifth day from leaving Port Said.

div.head: SICILY.
div.p: The direct route to Sicily is by the Florio-Rubattino Co.'s steamers which leave Alexandria weekly for MESSINA, where one takes train to TAORMENA, one of the most charming and popular places on the island. Giardini is the station at which to alight, and the drive up to Taormina is most delightful, occupying about one hour. In and around the town is much to interest the visitor. The theatre is of Greek origin, but restored under the Romans. CATANIA is the starting place for the ascent of Etna and here also is a fine Cathedral. The Greek, Roman, and Saracenic remains that are found all over the island, are an endless sources of pleasure. SYRACUSE has an interesting history, having been a Greek city, which was designed by Demosthenes in B.C. 413, and taken by the Romans in B.C. 212, when Archimedes was slain—his tomb is to be seen. The cathedral was once an ancient pagan temple. PALERMO, with about 300,000 inhabitants, is the capital of the Island, and enjoys a delightful climate. Much of interest is to be found in this fine city. The Palazzo Reale is of Saracenic origin and close to it the church of S. Giovannia degli Eremiti with its picturesque cloisters. The Cathedral, Museum, Botanic Gardens, Villa Giulia and Royal Park are also worth a visit.

div.head: CENTRAL ITALY.
div.p: The fine steamers of the North German Lloyd leave Alexandria every Wednesday during the season for Naples, the voyage being only 3 days.

NAPLES is also reached in 10 hours from Palermo by the Florio-Rubattino Co.'s steamers, which leave daily. One cannot approach Naples or leave it without wishing to explore some of its islands, besides the lovely places on its bay—Castellamare and Sorrento. The small steamer that takes you to Sorrento [you can drive too] will take you on to Capri.

From Naples to ROME is a train journey of but five hours. All who can will devote at least one week to visiting the many historical and interesting portions of the Eternal City, whose charms and beauties are too well-known to need comment here.

Leaving the Eternal City with much regret, a railway journey of five hours brings you to FLORENCE, where another week can well be spent admiring the City of Flowers and its surrounding country. In Florence itself the churches and galleries are of absorbing interest, whilst the local promenades and excursions should not be omitted. The Cascine is the most attractive and fashionable promenade in Florence, whilst the Viale dei Colli, one of the finest walks in Europe, opened 35 years ago, goes winding up through the hills a distance of four miles. The most delightful excursion outside Florence is that to Vallombrosa, with its Monastery 3,300 feet above the sea level. This is made first by ordinary train from Florence to St. Ellero, thence by cog-wheel railway to Saltino. The ascent through groves of oaks takes an hour, and most striking panoramas are unfolded to view.

PISA is easily reached from Florence in about 2 hours ; hero there is a fine Cathedral and the Leaning Tower. A stay of at least one night should if possible be made in order to enjoy the view from the Campanile at sunset.

VIAREGGIO. One of the most delightful places on the Italian Riviera near Pisa and on the main line from Rome to Genoa. It is a very convenient half-way house between Egypt and England, and where living is reasonable and the air and surroundings exceptionally good.

div.head: NORTHERN ITALY
div.p: GENOA (La Superba).—The most picturesque and interesting city in Italy, with the record of having one of the lowest death averages of European cities and a phenomenally equable temperature—warm in winter and deliciously cool breezes from the surrounding mountains and the Mediterranean in summer.

The patriarchal home of Italy's most ancient nobility, whose palaces, gardens, and famous collections of statuary, frescoes, and paintings, are a constant delight to thousands of travellers who annually sojourn in Genoa. Then there are the superbly decorated medieval churches containing exquisite marble columns and historical paintings, and the incomparable Campo Santo filled with its wonderful tombs.
From Genoa to Milan is a matter of only three hours by rail.

MILAN is a good centre for Northern Italy before making the tour of the Lakes. The Cathedral is the principal attraction, with its beautiful windows illustrating the History of the Bible. The public gardens and the monumental cemetery are also worth a visit.

Between Bologna and Milan and only an hour and a half from Milan is SALSOMAGGIORE, a renowned health resort on account of its thermal springs, change trains at Borgo San Donino and in half-an-hour you are at Salsomaggiore.
